children.subject: if you love math, consider the ML/DS pathway. EECS 126/127 are good math-y courses to help build that mathematical maturity for ML.

My mistake. 186 completely went over my head. 186 is useful too. Data 100 not so much if you are talking swe as it's more of a data analysis and techniques. I suggested 169 because it introduces you to web development, testing, a lot of frameworks, software development practices and lifecycles, etc.
To the students’ answer, any reason for 169 instead of 186 or 100?

I would not recommend Math 110 in Berkeley. It is poorly taught and less staff support. The material is pretty abstract and highly exam focused. Not really useful for ML/AI. However, putting yourself through that class gives you a mathematical maturity. Professors usually don't teach the sort of proof required for exams. So you have to do random homework questions and often the case you might not able to do everything for every single week and take the weekly quizzes. So if you want to really learn math, always go for the classes with better staff-support. One math class that will be really helpful for AI/ML is Math 104. Several Grad students personally recommended that class. Again abstract proving but more worth it. My opinion is suitable for someone who is above average in Math and want to learn the content by working through the material. However, if you are pretty comfortable with abstract proving, go for it. I was amazed to see some hardcore Math majors in the class. They were able to infer things quickly.
How useful is 170 for SWE compared to, say 186 or 162? i’m having a hard time convincing myself to study the last 1/3 of the class

I’d say it’s probably more important for getting a position (I.e. interview questions) than either of those. The last 1/3 of the class is a bit on the theoretical side but I found it to be the most interesting part of the class, and it does help in terms of building problem solving intuition. 162 is also a pretty important class for swe both in terms of the interview and the actual work you might do. 186 is pretty practical, I learned SQL programming outside of Berkeley so I probably wouldn’t take it, but in every one of my work experiences I have used sql or worked directly with some sort of database, it’s probably a good skill to pick up.

Here's an unpopular opinion: I found 170 not as useful as everyone makes it out to be, especially the entire second half of the course following greedy/DP. The usefulness of 170 in the context of industry is based on the need to develop the intuition to solve interview problems for SWE positions, a lot of which are algorithmic and a fair portion of which make use of concepts such as BFS/DFS/Greedy/DP/Divide & Conquer.  Beyond these concepts, everything else is usually too theoretical to be tested in a regular SWE interview. Now you may think that since half the course is crucial to interviewing, you might as well be better off taking it. However, in my personal experience, even the concepts that were useful were taught/explained in a manner that is too theoretical for the purposes of interviewing with the exception of maybe DP, since the recurrence relations are really the core of the algorithm and those are more or less the same as the pseudocode. If you want to develop intuition to solve the kinds of problems asked in interviews in an interview setting, I would recommend self-studying the relevant portions of 170 and practicing problems topic-wise from Leetcode/Hackerrank instead, which are a more accurate reflection of what interviews will be like. Alternatively, you can take the class P/NP and zone out at will.

Any course in the 16- series will probably be beneficial for software dev. since, at the least, they all provide programming assignments, and the individual courses can give you varying theoretical knowledge and practical skills. Of these, the more ubiquitous ones are 162, 161, while the others are either more specific or more "optional." To these I'd add 186, and 184 since these also involve extensive programming. 170 has almost no programming (final project has a little but it depends on your group); but a solid knowledge of algorithms is really useful for developers, most CS students take it at some point. 188 is probably a good mix of math and programming. If I were solely focused on SWE with no particular area of interest I'd probably personally take 170, 161, 162, 168/164, and 186 for my 5 upper divs.

history.content: Hi What upper division classes would you recommend for Software Developer? Also for someone who loves math what CS careers would you recommend to focus on?
history.subject: Classes recommendation for Software developer
